awd_titl_txt: Using the Susquehanna - Shale Hills CZO to Project from the Geological Past to the Anthropocene Future
awd_abstract_narration:
The Critical Zone (CZ) is the zone between the upper branches of trees and the depths of groundwater. Humans are changing this zone at geologically unprecedented rates.  Maintaining ecosystems will require the ability to project the future of the CZ.  Only with concerted efforts to measure and model the landscape will it be possible to make forward projections or "earthcasts" of the CZ.  

In the Susquehanna Shale Hills Critical Zone Observatory (CZO), scientists are working to earthcast the CZ by modeling aspects of the atmosphere, land surface, biota, soil, rocks and water. In addition, the models will eventually incorporate impacts of human activity. These models for water, energy, sediment, and solute (WESS) fluxes will be used to project changes spanning from 10^-3 y (water) to 10^6 y (soil).  For the sedimentary rocks underlying the CZO, the models will be used to explore how the geological past has impacted today?s land surface, and, in turn, how this structure contributes toward controlling today's water and gas fluxes. 

The central focus of the CZO is the forested Shale Hills watershed (~0.1 km2) but investigations will include the multiple-landuse Shavers Creek watershed (165 km2).  These nested watersheds will comprise the expanded Susquehanna Shale Hills Observatory (SSHO). This upscaling will force a transition from measuring "everything everywhere" to measuring "only what is needed" in a larger watershed with multiple rock types and land use.  The CZO will be used to test the over-arching hypothesis: To project CZ evolution into the future requires knowledge of geological history, observations of CZ processes today, and scenarios of human activities tomorrow.  

An important focus of the CZO will be to transfer knowledge to nonCZO scientists and to the public. For example, the CZO will develop hydrological models for two PA watersheds in the region of drilling and hydrofracking for shale gas in western and northern Pennsylvania. The public will also be engaged through a "CZO Four Seasons" music concert, where Penn State musicians will create a music score from many years of watershed data at the CZO.

por.por_cntn:
As humankind increasingly changes the surface of the Earth, it is imperative to learn to predict the impacts of such change. This project focussed on one watershed in central Pennsylvania as a location to study aspects of water, energy, gas, solute, and sediment cycling within the layer defined from the top of the vegetation canopy to the depths of groundwater. This layer, from trees to deep water, is termed the critical zone because it is critical to sustenance of humans on Earth. The project developed the idea that to understand the critical zone requires investigating the layer as a single entity, without reduction to the component parts. In a real sense, the team showed that understanding human impact on Earth requires understanding how the critical zone acts as a single entity. The main focus of the project was to develop quantitative understanding of the critical zone to enable short- and long-timescale quantitative predictions of how the zone changes over time. This forecasting was termed earthcasting. 

The activities included in this investigation of the critical zone incorporated measurements of samples and deployment of sensors, data management, modelling of data, development of theory, and testing of theory. The funded project, called the Susquehanna Shale Hills Critical Zone Observatory, was a premier facility for all of these activities. As one outcome of the Critical Zone Observatory, the Penn State Integrated Hydrological Model was developed with a set of modules focussed on different time scales of evolution of the critical zone. Students were educated in a variety of disciplines from soil science to geology to environmental engineering to meteorology to ecology to understand the functioning of the critical zone. Students were also taught to interact across disciplinary boundaries and to communicate with the public. As part of the observatory, researchers and students worked with many federal and state agencies as well as K12 educational institutions and community groups. Several museum installations were promoted to teach the public about the critical zone and how it works, including installations in Pennsylvania and in Europe. The team discovered hidden impacts from metal deposition on Pennsylvania soils throughout the industrial age of the USA , new methods for modeling how water moves through the critical zone, new techniques to model biological processing of energy and nutrients, a new technique to use soil gas chemistry and electrode installations to interpret the sources of energy and carbon used by soil bacteria, and the use of new electrical resistivity and seismic methods to probe the deep critical zone.  The ultimate result of this critical zone observatory, operating as part of a network of observatories nationwide, was the development of critical zone science as a new and burgeoning focus of scientific endeavor. Hundreds of critical zone observatories have now been established worldwide and universities now hire in this new and growing scientific area.


Last Modified: 03/20/2022
Modified by: Susan L Brantley
